{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox military installation | name = New Fortress | native_name = Νέο Φρούριο | partof = the defences of [[Corfu City]] | location = [[Corfu (city)|Corfu]], [[Greece]] | image = [[File:Corfou-ville-nouvelle citadelle.jpg|300px]] | caption = | map_type = | map_relief = | latitude = 39.623 | longitude = 19.912 | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | type = | coordinates = | coord_region = | code = | built = 1572–1645 | builder = | materials = | height = | used = | demolished = | condition = | ownership = {{flag|Greece}} | open_to_public = | controlledby = [[Republic of Venice]] (until 1797), [[France]] (1797–99, 1807–14), [[Septinsular Republic]] (1800–15), [[United Kingdom]] (1815–64), [[Greece]] (since 1864) | garrison = | current_commander = | commanders = | occupants = | battles = [[Siege of Corfu (1798–99)]], [[Corfu Incident]] | events = }} The '''New Fortress of Corfu''' ({{lang-gr|Νέο Φρούριο}}, {{Lang-vec|Fortezza Nuova}}) is a [[Republic of Venice|Venetian]] fortress built on the hill of St. Mark in [[Corfu]] in stages. The original architect of the fort was the military engineer Ferrante Vitelli. The current buildings which exist within the fortress were built by the British during their [[United States of the Ionian Islands|rule of the island]] (1815–63).<ref name=Stamatopoulos>{{cite book|author=Nondas Stamatopoulos|title=Old Corfu: history and culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6m0-AQAAIAAJ|year=1993|publisher=N. Stamatopoulos|page=162|quote=The New Fortress was built on the hill of St. Mark between 1572 and 1645, the military engineer ...}}</ref>
At the top of the castle there is a stone building which was used for defence and a brick building which in modern times functions as the headquarters of the Naval Station of Corfu.<ref name=Stamatopoulos/> The Venetian fortifications were later expanded by the British and the French to help defend against a possible Turkish attack.<ref name="Fodor's2011">{{cite book|author=Fodor's|title=Fodor's Greece|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A1bAJ6kgi84C&pg=PA386|date=21 June 2011|publisher=Fodor's Travel Publications|isbn=978-0-307-92863-4|page=386}}</ref> Its fortifications included 700 pieces of artillery with range estimated as far as the Albanian coast.<ref name="Braudel1995">{{cite book|author=Fernand Braudel|title=The Mediterranean and the Mediterranean World in the Age of Philip II|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yAMe0bu3Jt4C&pg=PA126|year=1995|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-20308-2|pages=126–129}}</ref>
==Origins== [[File:Neo Frourio in Corfu.jpg|thumb|300px|New Fortress of Corfu]]
In the aftermath of the [[Siege of Corfu (1537)|first great Ottoman siege]] of Corfu in 1537, the Venetians developed plans to expand the fortifications of the city.<ref name=Stamatopoulos/><ref name=Miller/>
Furthermore, due to the great civilian losses, the Corfu city council sent diplomatic representatives to Venice complaining about the lack of fortifications for the parts of the city of Corfu lying outside the walls of the medieval citadel. In response, the Venetians proceeded with works to build walls and fortifications to strengthen the defences of the wider town lying outside the walls of the old citadel.<ref name=Stamatopoulos/><ref name=Miller>{{cite book|title=Essays on the Latin Orient|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wcw7AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA221|publisher=CUP Archive|pages=220–221|id=GGKEY:JQX2NJ8ZB5P}}</ref>
To achieve their goals the Venetians razed 2,000 homes in the suburb of San Rocco, and built new fortifications and walls in their place at great expense. After the fortification works were completed the Venetians built the New Fortress at the hill of St. Mark to further strengthen the defences of the outer city of Corfu and to act as the focal point of the new fortifications. The exact dating of the structure is not established but accounts vary between 1576 or 1577-1588,<ref name=Miller/><ref name="Tataki">{{cite book|author=A. B. Tataki (Director of Research of the [[National Hellenic Research Foundation]])|title=Corfu: History, Monuments, Museums|url=|accessdate=|year=1983|publisher=Ekdotike Athenon S.A.|pages=47–48|quote=}}</ref> and 1572-1645.<ref name=Stamatopoulos/> The start date for the construction is also reported as 1577 by Corfiote historian Katsaros.<ref name="Katsaros2003">{{cite book|author1=Spyros Katsaros|title=Ιστορία της Κέρκυρας|year=2003|isbn=960-87976-0-8|publisher=Mellon|page=261}}</ref> The works had also the effect of widening the defensive perimeter of the old citadel lying inside the Old Fortress.<ref name=Stamatopoulos/><ref name=Miller/>
==Architectural details== [[File:Neo Frourio by the sea.jpg|thumb|300px|The New Fortress as seen from the old port of Corfu]] The Fortress compound is divided into two levels. In the lower level there is a three-storey building called "Punta Perpetua" and a bastion of pentagonal shape.<ref name=UNESCO>{{cite web|title=World Heritage Site Nomination|url=http://whc.unesco.org/uploads/nominations/978.pdf|publisher=UNESCO|page=5}}</ref>
Inside the bastion there is a maze of arched chambers, galleries, ventilation shafts, stairs and ramps. The fortress has two [[baroque]]-styled gates. Its western side features a dry moat which spans the length of the walls, running from the vegetable market to the new harbour. The moat is a good example of moat architecture.<ref name=Stamatopoulos/><ref name="Edwards2003">{{cite book|author=Nick Edwards|title=The Rough Guide to Corfu|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iZxBjje_CosC&pg=PA87|year=2003|publisher=Rough Guides|isbn=978-1-84353-038-1|page=87}}</ref>
The structure features twin bastions one of which is called "Bastion of the Seven Winds". The bastion has a commanding view of the sea and the mountains of mainland Greece. Below the bastion there is a building which was built by the British and functioned as military barracks. Nowadays it houses art exhibits and collections as well as space for social events.<ref name="Corfu city hall">{{cite web|script-title=el:Νέο Φρούριο ( 1587 μ.Χ.)|url=http://www.corfu.gr/web/guest/visitor/sights/fortress/new|publisher=Corfu city hall|language=Greek}}</ref>
The bastion is at a height of 55 m above sea level and features structures such as underground cisterns, powder magazines, artillery positions and underground halls.<ref name="Corfu city hall"/>
==Governor of the castle== [[File:Venetian blazon in Corfu.jpg|thumb|300px|Venetian [[blazon]] with the [[Lion of Saint Mark]], as frequently found on the New Fortress walls.]] The governors of the Old and New Fortresses were elected by the [[Venetian Senate]] for a period of two years. Both captains were sworn before the Senate and part of their oath was to never communicate with each other during their two-year tenure as governors of the fortresses. This was for security reasons in case one captain could persuade the other to commit treason against the Republic.<ref name="Lithgow1770">{{cite book|author=[[William Lithgow (traveller and author)|William Lithgow]]|title=Travels and Voyages Through Europe, Asia, and Africa, for Nineteen Years ...|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r9UWAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA59|year=1770|publisher=J. Meuros|pages=59–60}}</ref>
==Destruction of fortifications== The sea defences of the New Fortress were destroyed by the British when the [[United States of the Ionian Islands|British protectorate]] came to an end and Corfu was united with Greece in 1864.<ref name="Miller2013"/> Under the same agreement, the Avrami and [[Vido]] island forts were also destroyed. When the latter fort was demolished, the explosion was so strong that it broke house windows on the Corfu side of the sea channel.<ref name="Miller2013">{{cite book | last = Miller | first = William | authorlink= William Miller (historian) |title=Ottoman Empire and Its Successors 1801-1927: With an Appendix, 1927-1936|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MFHL6H9JTmAC&pg=PA289|date=13 June 2013|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-107-68659-5|pages=288–289}}</ref>
==Bombardment== In 1923 the New and Old Fortresses were bombarded by the Italian Air Force during the [[Corfu Incident]]. [[Greek refugees]] from [[Asia Minor]] were sheltered inside the New Fort at the time but there were no casualties.<ref name="Mouratidēs2005">{{cite book|author=Spyridōn Mouratidēs|title=Prosphyges tēs Mikras Asias, Pontou kai Anatolikēs Thrakēs stēn Kerkyra 1922-1932|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KFtoAAAAMAAJ&q=%CE%9D%CE%AD%CE%BF+%CE%A6%CF%81%CE%BF%CF%8D%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%BF&dq=%CE%9D%CE%AD%CE%BF+%CE%A6%CF%81%CE%BF%CF%8D%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%BF|year=2005|publisher=Themelio|page=77}}</ref>
